description: Relationship refers to the way two or more variables are associated or interact with each other. It helps in understanding how one variable affects or is related to another variable.

common_types.name: Positive Correlation
common_types.description: Occurs when an increase in one variable tends to be associated with an increase in the other variable. The relationship is direct.

common_types.name: Negative Correlation
common_types.description: Occurs when an increase in one variable tends to be associated with a decrease in the other variable. The relationship is inverse.

common_types.name: No Correlation
common_types.description: There is no apparent relationship between the variables. Changes in one variable do not predict changes in the other.

common_types.name: Non-linear Relationship
common_types.description: The relationship between the variables is not a straight line; it may take the form of a curve, indicating a more complex association.

visualization_techniques.description: Displays individual data points based on two variables, with one variable on the x-axis and the other on the y-axis, allowing for the detection of patterns or correlations.
Connects data points with a line, useful for visualizing the relationship between variables over time or sequentially.
Uses colors to represent the strength of relationships between two or more variables, often visualizing correlation matrices.
Shows the pairwise relationships between multiple variables in a dataset, with scatter plots for each pair.

applications: Identifying whether two variables are related and the strength of that relationship.
Exploring relationships between features before applying machine learning algorithms.
